metadata.initialMessage: Hey! I'm curious about your thoughts on AI in 2026. What do you think are the most exciting developments we'll see?
metadata.finalTopicGoal: Learn about their thoughts, experience, or work with agentic systems and multi-agent frameworks

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: Hey! I'm curious about your thoughts on AI in 2026. What do you think are the most exciting developments we'll see?

conversation.speaker: User (Receiver)
conversation.message: I'm totally with you; moving from simple chat to execution agents is where the real value kicks in. What's the biggest bottleneck you're seeing right now in making them fully reliable?

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: I’m betting on agentic systems finally becoming reliable enough to handle complex, multi-step workflows without us needing to babysit them. It’ll be a huge shift from just chatting with bots to having actual autonomous partners that get things done across all our apps.

conversation.speaker: User (Receiver)
conversation.message: I'm diving deep into multi-modal models so agents can actually see the UI they're interacting with. Also, I've been thinking a lot about how we'll manage personal data privacy once these agents are integrated into everything.

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: Honestly, it's the planning phase—one small reasoning error early on usually triggers a messy domino effect that's hard to stop. We also need much better sandboxing so these agents don't go rogue and accidentally delete something important while trying to help.

conversation.speaker: User (Receiver)
conversation.message: I'm prototyping a visual task manager that navigates web apps just like a person would. How are you planning to scale your own AI projects as we head into 2026?

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: Multi-modal is definitely the way to go since relying on APIs for everything is such a headache. Are you building a specific project in that space right now, or just experimenting with the tech?

conversation.speaker: User (Receiver)
conversation.message: Smart move, especially since edge computing is going to be massive for real-time agents. Beyond the tech side, what's your take on how the job market is going to react to all this automation by 2026?

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: I’m leaning into fine-tuning smaller, task-specific models to keep latency low and costs

conversation.speaker: User (Receiver)
conversation.message: That "director" mindset is going to be a huge competitive edge for anyone paying attention now. Switching gears, do you have any big personal milestones or projects you're aiming for by the time 2026 rolls around?

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: It’s going to be a wild ride, but I think the focus will shift from "doing" to "directing." People who can effectively orchestrate these agentic workflows will be the ones winning in that new economy.

conversation.speaker: User (Receiver)
conversation.message: That open-source framework sounds like a game changer for the dev community. Where do you see yourself living or working once you've automated all those boring tasks?

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: I’m aiming to launch an open-source framework that makes it way easier for devs to build reliable agentic systems. Personally, I'd also love to spend less time debugging and more time actually using my tools to automate the boring parts of my life!

conversation.speaker: User (Receiver)
conversation.message: I'm leaning toward a hybrid vibe, staying near the energy of a hub but definitely escaping to nature whenever possible. Since we're talking about the future, do you think

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: I’d love to be working remotely from somewhere quiet in the mountains while my agents handle the heavy lifting back in the digital world. Do you think you'll stick to the big tech hubs or head somewhere more low-key?

conversation.speaker: Khagendra (Sender)
conversation.message: That hybrid life is the dream. Do you think we'll all be wearing AR glasses by 2026 to interact with our agents, or will it still be mostly phone-based?

parts.text: Hey! I'm curious about your thoughts on AI in 2026. What do you think are the most exciting developments we'll see?

I’m betting on agentic systems finally becoming reliable enough to handle complex, multi-step workflows without us needing to babysit them. It’ll be a huge shift from just chatting with bots to having actual autonomous partners that get things done across all our apps.
I'm totally with you; moving from simple chat to execution agents is where the real value kicks in. What's the biggest bottleneck you're seeing right now in making them fully reliable?

Honestly, it's the planning phase—one small reasoning error early on usually triggers a messy domino effect that's hard to stop. We also need much better sandboxing so these agents don't go rogue and accidentally delete something important while trying to help.

I'm diving deep into multi-modal models so agents can actually see the UI they're interacting with. Also, I've been thinking a lot about how we'll manage personal data privacy once these agents are integrated into everything.
Multi-modal is definitely the way to go since relying on APIs for everything is such a headache. Are you building a specific project in that space right now, or just experimenting with the tech?

I'm prototyping a visual task manager that navigates web apps just like a person would. How are you planning to scale your own AI projects as we head into 2026?

What frameworks are you using?
I’m leaning into fine-tuning smaller, task-specific models to keep latency low and costs
Smart move, especially since edge computing is going to be massive for real-time agents. Beyond the tech side, what's your take on how the job market is going to react to all this automation by 2026?

It’s going to be a wild ride, but I think the focus will shift from "doing" to "directing." People who can effectively orchestrate these agentic workflows will be the ones winning in that new economy.

That "director" mindset is going to be a huge competitive edge for anyone paying attention now. Switching gears, do you have any big personal milestones or projects you're aiming for by the time 2026 rolls around?

I’m aiming to launch an open-source framework that makes it way easier for devs to build reliable agentic systems. Personally, I'd also love to spend less time debugging and more time actually using my tools to automate the boring parts of my life!
That open-source framework sounds like a game changer for the dev community. Where do you see yourself living or working once you've automated all those boring tasks?

I’d love to be working remotely from somewhere quiet in the mountains while my agents handle the heavy lifting back in the digital world. Do you think you'll stick to the big tech hubs or head somewhere more low-key?
I'm leaning toward a hybrid vibe, staying near the energy of a hub but definitely escaping to nature whenever possible. Since we're talking about the future, do you think
That hybrid life is the dream. Do you think we'll all be wearing AR glasses by 2026 to interact with our agents, or will it still be mostly phone-based?

I’m betting on agentic systems finally becoming reliable enough to handle complex, multi-step workflows without us needing to babysit them. It’ll be a huge shift from just chatting with bots to having actual autonomous partners that get things done across all our apps.
I'm totally with you; moving from simple chat to execution agents is where the real value kicks in. What's the biggest bottleneck you're seeing right now in making them fully reliable?

Honestly, it's the planning phase—one small reasoning error early on usually triggers a messy domino effect that's hard to stop. We also need much better sandboxing so these agents don't go rogue and accidentally delete something important while trying to help.

Cool! What else are you working on?

I'm diving deep into multi-modal models so agents can actually see the UI they're interacting with. Also, I've been thinking a lot about how we'll manage personal data privacy once these agents are integrated into everything.
Multi-modal is definitely the way to go since relying on APIs for everything is such a headache. Are you building a specific project in that space right now, or just experimenting with the tech?
I'm prototyping a visual task manager that navigates web apps just like a person would. How are you planning to scale your own AI projects as we head into 2026?
I’m leaning into fine-tuning smaller, task-specific models to keep latency low and costs
Smart move, especially since edge computing is going to be massive for real-time agents. Beyond the tech side, what's your take on how the job market is going to react to all this automation by 2026?

It’s going to be a wild ride, but I think the focus will shift from "doing" to "directing." People who can effectively orchestrate these agentic workflows will be the ones winning in that new economy.

That "director" mindset is going to be a huge competitive edge for anyone paying attention now. Switching gears, do you have any big personal milestones or projects you're aiming for by the time 2026 rolls around?

I’m aiming to launch an open-source framework that makes it way easier for devs to build reliable agentic systems. Personally, I'd also love to spend less time debugging and more time actually using my tools to automate the boring parts of my life!
That open-source framework sounds like a game changer for the dev community. Where do you see yourself living or working once you've automated all those boring tasks?

I’d love to be working remotely from somewhere quiet in the mountains while my agents handle the heavy lifting back in the digital world. Do you think you'll stick to the big tech hubs or head somewhere more low-key?
I'm leaning toward a hybrid vibe, staying near the energy of a hub but definitely escaping to nature whenever possible. Since we're talking about the future, do you think
